Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Institutional Arrangements and the Incorporation of Immigrant Populations

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Ethnic diversity is a common characteristic of urban environments and some European cities have become "super diverse" over the last decade. In response to this superdiversity, nations in Western Europe have created urban reception offices for newly arrived migrants. It is in these reception offices that local understandings of citizenship and incorporation are communicated and translated through citizenship classes.

As a social phenomenon, the emergence of reception offices for the sake of incorporating newly arrived immigrants speaks towards a shift in emphasis from the legal to the moral dimensions of citizenship. In other words, in order for migrants to be considered citizens, they not only have to obtain the appropriate legal documents, but they also have to display "good moral character." Studies on these aspects of citizenship are relatively scarce. Nevertheless, they are important in order to get a better understanding of the theoretical categories of citizenship and incorporation. It implies studying who is included in the imagined community of citizens and who is not.

This dissertation utilizes ethnographic research to investigate how newcomer migrants are welcomed in practice in the bilingual and multi-institutional city of Brussels, Belgium. Specifically, by comparing the French-speaking and the Flemish-speaking welcoming practices, the study aims to understand how and why new moral citizens are produced in an urban environment were there is no uniform vision on the governance of newcomers. This research will thus shed light on the micro processes whereby new moral citizens are produced as well as provide insight into denationalized forms of moral citizenship. This is then generalizable as information to advance theories of migration and integration and becomes useful as evidence for developing effective strategies for stakeholders involved in this process around the world.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In times of global migration, cities have become important sites of citizenship. Although diversity has always been a central feature of urban environments, European cities have become 'super diverse' over the last decade. In response to superdiversity, notions of belonging and membership are increasingly negotiated at the urban level. Governments in countries like France, the Netherlands, Germany and Belgium started setting up urban reception offices for newly arrived migrants. It is in these reception offices that understandings of citizenship are communicated and translated through citizenship classes. As a social phenomenon, the emergence of reception offices speaks towards a shift in emphasis from legal status to the moral dimensions of citizenship. In other words, in order for migrants to be considered citizens, they not only have to obtain the right documents, but they also have to display ‘good moral character’.

This study investigated how newcomer migrants are welcomed in practice in the bilingual and multi-institutional city of Brussels. More specifically, by comparing the French-speaking and the Flemish-speaking welcoming practices, the researcher studied how new moral citizens are produced in an urban environment where there is no uniform vision on the governance of newcomers.

Building primarily on an ethnography of citizenship classes, semi-structured interviews and archival sources and secondary data, the researcher argues that through boundary making processes the two linguistic communities determine what it means to be a good citizen. I demonstrated the varying conceptions the francophone and the Flemish community have of citizenship.

In Brussels, the officially bilingual capital of Belgium, the categories of citizenship are questioned constantly. Symbolic and practical boundaries are drawn between French-speaking and Flemish-speaking elites and between citizens and newcomers in the field of newcomer reception. This field is thus an excellent site to study how urban, regional and transnational claims to moral citizenship are governed, negotiated and contested in practice. While notions of moral citizenship have been studied on the level of the nation-state, the city as a meaningful level of identity-formation is often neglected. This research focuses on the study of denationalized forms of citizenship, like regional and urban allegiances. In an increasingly cosmopolitan city like Brussels, the promotion of Flemish-ness or a distinctive francophone identity becomes a peculiar anomaly that does not stroke with urban reality. The findings not only shed light on the micro processes whereby new moral citizens are produced, but also encourage more research about the importance of sub-national forms of moral citizenship. This study thus provides insight in a world where many cities have become ‘minority-majority citites’ and where different forms of belonging are negotiated on a daily basis.

The governance of newcomer migrants is a relatively new area of policy in Europe. While some studies have been done about the governance of newcomers at the policy level, few studies investigate how such policies are put into practice in reception offices. This study’s findings therefore have a potential impact for several non-academic audiences at multiple levels. At the level of newcomer reception offices, this study explicates the assumptions and logics of operation that underlie these offices’ everyday activities. Furthermore, newcomers’ responses towards organizational approaches to citizenship are researched as well.
